Description: Pair of woven palm leaf sandals, with toe ends curled upwards and joining the loop passing over the instep. These sandals have also been provided with high sides, creating a more shoe-like appearance. The sole is formed from a piece of widely-plaited palm fibre, stitched to sides of finer woven palm.
Curator's comments: These are likely to be from a high status tomb, as sandals were a common part of the elite New Kingdom burial assemblage (Smith, MDAIK 48 [1992]: 209-10). The form of sandals Louvre N1308 replicates that of EA 4464. See V. Montembault. Catalogue des Chaussures de l'Antiquité Égyptienne (Louvre Catalogue, Paris, 2000: 36-7). It has been suggested that sandals with upturned toes were introduced in the Ramesside era (John McDonald, in Egypt’s Golden Age [exhibition catalogue, Boston, 1982]: 177-8).
Bibliographic references: Veldmeijer 2009b / Studies of ancient Egyptian footwear. Technological aspects. Part XII. Fibre shoes (99-100, 102, 105, 110, fig.2c)
